Watford...Est. 188ish. Played at Vicarage Road since 1927. Rivals: Historically, Luton Town. But they're rubbish. Something of a modern rivalry with Palace Leicester. Most Watford supporters don't like Arsenal Spurs as they're local, but they don't really care about us.
Highest ever finish was 2nd in the pre-Premier League top division in 1983. It was followed by an FA Cup final appearance in 1984.
Best ever manager is Graham Taylor who took us from the old Division 4 to runners up in 6 seasons. Then returned in 1997 to take us from league 1 back into the Premier League.
Greatest Ever Player is probably Luther Blissett, highest ever goalscorer who played for the club in the 70s, 80s 90s. Closely followed by John Barnes. Of the modern crop, Troy Deeney has become the first player to score 20 goals in 3 consecutive seasons. He's unlikely to get 20 this year, but is the talismanic captain who the club persevered with after he went to jail for kicking a student's head in. He's rewarded that with an absurd level of performance.
Fun Fact! We're owned by the same people as Udinese Granada. We've benefited from a number of players such as Odion Ighalo (Udinese), Almen Abdi (Udinese) Allan Nyom (Granada)

Troy Deeney.
Closely followed by Igoalho, Gomes Capoue

As an Englander, I've always found Stonehenge cold and dull, but if you're heading that way, Salisbury cathedral is wonderful. I also think the cabinet war rooms whilst interesting, are a little over priced.
That said, the West Kensington museums (Victoria and Albert, Science and Natural History) are outstanding, and the Imperial War Museum is incredible.
The Globe is magnificent as well.
For evening activities, you cab usually pick up cheapish tickets for West End musicals on the day, if he's into that. If it's March, and you're into soccer, there's probably a good chance of a midweek game at one of the lower league London teams (Brentford, Leyton Orient, QPR) which shouldn't be too expensive either.
I can't speak for the Erie Divisie, but the A league is not as good as the Championship. It's certainly similar in style, but an average Championship team would, I reckon, demolish an A league team.

As my understanding of doping goes, by the time that the athletes have got to a competition like the Olympics, they wouldn't have taken anything for some time, but already derived the benefits. That's why the out of competition testing is so important.
As it goes, I'm not convinced that the entire British team is as clean as it like to claim, and I find it very hard to believe that across the major sports in the UK (football, rugby (both codes), athletics etc) so few sportsmen women are caught for anything other than recreational drug use.
